articles.headline: Martin Baron, Who Led Three Major Papers, Retires From Washington Post
articles.snippet: After leading journalists to Pulitzer Prizes in Miami, Boston and Washington, The Post’s executive editor said he would call it a career on Feb. 28.
articles.abstract: After leading journalists to Pulitzer Prizes in Miami, Boston and Washington, The Post’s executive editor said he would call it a career on Feb. 28.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Baron, a newsroom giant who led The Washington Post, The Boston Globe and The Miami Herald to numerous Pulitzer Prizes in a career noted for groundbreaking reports on the National Security Agency’s secret surveillance program and serial sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic church, said on Tuesday that he will retire on Feb. 28 after eight years as The Post’s executive editor.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and Marc Tracy

articles.headline: Proud Boys Under Growing Scrutiny in Capitol Riot Investigation
articles.snippet: Officials are trying to determine to what extent far-right groups planned the assault in advance.
articles.abstract: Officials are trying to determine to what extent far-right groups planned the assault in advance.
articles.lead_paragraph: The leadership of the Proud Boys has come under increased scrutiny as agents and prosecutors across the country try to determine how closely members of the far-right nationalist group communicated during the riot at the Capitol this month and to what extent they might have planned the assault in advance, according to federal law enforcement officials.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Frances Robles

articles.headline: What Jeffrey Epstein Did to Earn $158 Million From Leon Black
articles.snippet: Mr. Epstein specialized in aggressively pitching ways to minimize paying taxes. And not just to Mr. Black, the private equity chief executive who was his main benefactor in his later years.
articles.abstract: Mr. Epstein specialized in aggressively pitching ways to minimize paying taxes. And not just to Mr. Black, the private equity chief executive who was his main benefactor in his later years.
articles.lead_paragraph: He styled himself as a math whiz and “financial doctor” to the rich — even though he was a college dropout who had only a brief tenure at a traditional Wall Street firm. It was said his services were available only to billionaires, whose affairs he handled mostly from a tropical island hideaway.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Biden Pledges to Speed Flow of Vaccines to the States
articles.snippet: President Biden said the number of coronavirus vaccines reaching the states would rise next week and a deal was near to provide enough shots to vaccinate nearly all Americans by the end of summer.
articles.abstract: President Biden said the number of coronavirus vaccines reaching the states would rise next week and a deal was near to provide enough shots to vaccinate nearly all Americans by the end of summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden, under intense pressure to speed up the pace of coronavirus vaccination, said Tuesday that his administration was nearing a deal with two manufacturers that would enable 300 million Americans to have their shots by the end of the summer.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Republicans Rally Against Impeachment Trial, Signaling Likely Acquittal for Trump
articles.snippet: All but five Republican senators voted to challenge the constitutionality of the trial, suggesting that Democrats were unlikely to find the 17 they would need to join them in convicting the former president.
articles.abstract: All but five Republican senators voted to challenge the constitutionality of the trial, suggesting that Democrats were unlikely to find the 17 they would need to join them in convicting the former president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans rallied on Tuesday against trying former President Donald J. Trump for “incitement of insurrection” at the Capitol, with only five members of his party joining Democrats in a vote to go forward with his impeachment trial.

articles.headline: Capitol Police Detail Failures During Pro-Trump Assault
articles.snippet: The acting chief of the Capitol Police told lawmakers that the department knew days ahead of time of the risk of violence targeting lawmakers but was unprepared when the mob attacked on Jan. 6.
articles.abstract: The acting chief of the Capitol Police told lawmakers that the department knew days ahead of time of the risk of violence targeting lawmakers but was unprepared when the mob attacked on Jan. 6.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Capitol Police department on Tuesday delivered to Congress its first after-action report since the deadly pro-Trump assault on the Capitol, laying out a dismal picture of failure to prepare adequately despite knowing days ahead of time that right-wing extremists could target lawmakers.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater, Emily Cochrane and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: E.U. and U.K. Fighting Over Scarce Vaccines
articles.snippet: As vaccine production falls behind schedule, and the European Union lags in inoculating people, Brussels and London are lobbing threats and accusations at each other.
articles.abstract: As vaccine production falls behind schedule, and the European Union lags in inoculating people, Brussels and London are lobbing threats and accusations at each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The vaccine wars have come to Europe.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: MyPillow C.E.O.’s Trump Conspiracy Theories Put Company on the Spot
articles.snippet: Retailers have stopped carrying its products, though Mike Lindell, the founder and face of MyPillow, blamed “cancel culture” and said he didn’t think it would last.
articles.abstract: Retailers have stopped carrying its products, though Mike Lindell, the founder and face of MyPillow, blamed “cancel culture” and said he didn’t think it would last.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past four years, most American corporations have tried to avoid the appearance of partisanship while also distancing themselves from the inflammatory rhetoric of former President Donald J. Trump and his supporters, walking a tightrope to keep customers and employees happy.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: The Reality Behind Biden’s Plan to Legalize 11 Million Immigrants
articles.snippet: The proposal for a path to citizenship for undocumented residents has been called “the boldest immigration agenda any administration has put forward in generations.” But is it possible?
articles.abstract: The proposal for a path to citizenship for undocumented residents has been called “the boldest immigration agenda any administration has put forward in generations.” But is it possible?
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Maria Elena Hernandez recently retrieved a flowery box tucked in her closet and dusted it off. For more than a decade, she has used it to store tax returns, lease agreements and other documents that she has collected to prove her family’s long years of residence in the United States.
